My point is that the riot team coded these abilities into the game, what went through their head to call them projectiles when they clearly aren't?

Because they are?

I defined what a projectile is. That's Riot's standard. 

Just like "jumps" still are coded as dashes, projectiles are a basic element of the game and have a particular definition and behavior pattern.

https://www.physicsclassroom.com/class/vectors/Lesson-2/What-is-a-Projectile

A projectile fly's, it doesnt run like a ram

And is the game set in real life?

Don't apply real world physics to a game.
https://pre00.deviantart.net/4b3b/th/pre/i/2014/090/e/7/_so_hard_to_be_a_flamer___1_nami_wanted_to_help_by_kahr_noss-d71wf2z.jpg

Why are you trying to make a "logic" argument in a video game where people use instant transmission, summon flames out of midair, fire bus-sized arrows with zero air resistance and zero mass, hover in the air, and turn into fucking dragons?

If we apply "logic" to Ashe's ult, then she'd have to fire it straight up in the air and turn it into a ground AoE like Xerath ult.

Normally I would say it is somewhat acceptable since it is way easier to code an all encompassing solution (like if ability starts from point A then moves to point B, or if the ability covers the distance between point A and point B). With so many different abilities, it would take a lot of time off their hands to just do it like this. 

But then you get shit like this where {{champion:161}} has 3(4) unique interactions with Yasuo's windwall (Q is blocked, W is stopped but what is already placed will still work, E is blocked but will still detonate because of a possible bug, and his ult is not effected at all). This clearly shows some level of micromanaging and not just some overall rule scheme (like if (isProjectile == true){ blocked = true;}).

Some of those may be bugs, yes, but for Vel'Koz's ult, it isn't blocked because it isn't a projectile.

There is no travel time for LFDR. It damages everything caught in its range at the same time. That's something classified as a laser. Other examples (that I remember off the top of my head) are Lux Ult and Xerath Q

The game is full of basic abilities stopping ultimates. Yasuo's W isn't even the only intercept.

It is though the only one that can protect **an entire team**, **without any charge up time**, by flat out cancelling **multiple** enemy ultimates.
Personally I'd be happy if at least the WindWall was cancelled by the first ultimate it blocked, so that he can't just cut a whole team out of the fight with 1 base spell only.

Mmmm on a second thought, scratch that: I'd be happy if WindWall was removed from the game and replaced with an actual base spell, instead of being a second ultimate in a base spell's clothing.

And, again, you can interrupt channeled ults with a variety of non-ult abilities, projectile ults (even point-and-click ones) can often be negated with untargetability, and so on. Yasuo's W is not the only basic ability that affects ults.

Just because something is an ult doesn't mean it's 100% guaranteed to do exactly what you want it to do with no counterplay. Cry that I'm "just wrong" all you want, but anyone who insists on unloading their projectile-based kit into an intercept and hoping that it somehow gets through this time will be disappointed.

Well not really, since there are dashes, knockbacks, and "minions".
In particular, Sion's E through minion, spooky ghosts, and Mist Walkers jumping from Yorick's E.
Wind wall also blocks things like Graves autos and Swain Q, which are both instantaneous.
There's also things like Fizz's ult or Orianna's balls that get stopped but don't disappear, and also Aurelion Sol's stars that go through Wind Wall.

This doesn't necessarily mean Yasuo is broken/overpowered/whatever, but over the years the logic around Wind Wall has been becoming more and more confusing.
